data.title: Taiwan Fruits from a Taiwanese Street Vendor
data.meta_description: Sugar Apples, Wax Apples, Durians - these are just some of the Taiwan Fruit you can find at a Street Market! Check out rest of these Fruits.
data.text:
Sharing is caring!

Being in the subtropical zone, Taiwan is in a great location for growing all sorts of delicious fruit, and is also pretty well known for the fruit produced. Not only is there an abundant amount of fruit, but they are also all delicious! These are the Taiwanese Fruits from a Taiwanese Street Vendor I saw while I visited.

Taiwan Climate and Taiwan Fruit

With hot humid summers and short winters as well as high precipitation, Taiwan‚Äôs climate is perfect for growing tropical fruits! So in this article you will see lots of delicious tropical Taiwan Fruit!

Yellow Watermelons

You can actually also find Yellow Watermelons here in the states, but not as commonly as in Taiwan. These yellow-interior watermelons are in any of the grocery stores in Taiwan. Yellow watermelons have a sweeter, honey-like flavor compared to their red counter parts, but nutrition wise, they are basically the same!

Taiwanese Guavas

Guavas can also be found here, but the ones I‚Äôve seen are NOT as beautiful as the ones I find in Taiwan. Not even close. Those here are all tiny, and when I tried buying some once, they were not nearly as sweet as those from Taiwan. Taiwanese Guavas are big, round, juicy, and delicious!

Starfruits (aka Carambola)

First of all, look how cool they look! Can you see why they are called ‚ÄúStarfruit‚Äù?

The taste, if I HAD to describe it using the taste of other fruits‚Ä¶ is a little bit citrus-y and apples and plums? If they are super ripe, they are super sweet, if not so ripe, they taste a bit more sour. Well, that‚Äôs the best I can do with describing the flavor.

Papaya

The papayas found in Taiwan have the same story as guavas. Yes, you can find them here in the states, but they are not nearly as ginormous or sweet/yummy. Also, they are a lot more commonly eaten here (just like the guavas).

Also, fun fact, a very popular beverage in Taiwan is called Papaya Milk ‚Äì it‚Äôs basically a smoothie made with the flesh of the papaya and fresh milk, and it is super tasty.

Wax Apples

I haven‚Äôt seen these in the States before, so I believe if you can, it is very rare to find‚Ä¶ These babies are called Wax Apples‚Ä¶ or apparently any of the following names: Champoo, love apple, java apple, royal apple, bellfruit, Jamaican apple, water apple, mountain apple, cloud apple, wax jambu, rose apple, and bell fruit.

Don‚Äôt be mistakened by the name, it doesn‚Äôt tastes or feel like apple at all. I think the only reason it is called that is because it‚Äôs red‚Ä¶and is a fruit. They are way softer than apples, and not as sweet/crunchy. I do love these a lot, and just realized I didn‚Äôt have any this trip back to Taiwan! üôÅ

Durians

These fruits can be BIG (as wiki puts it: 30 centimetres (12 in) long and 15 centimetres (6 in) in diameter, and it typically weighs one to three kilograms (2 to 7 lb)), but that‚Äôs not the most recognizable trait of Durians. That‚Ä¶would actually be the distinct SMELL of the fruit. Some people like the smell, some people HATE it with a passion. I agree with both somehow, but I definitely think it tastes kind of‚Ä¶ yummy. You see, if you don‚Äôt know what you‚Äôre expecting, it‚Äôs custard-like texture might be a surprise.

Here it is being split up and making some people cringe and some people get hungry with its smell:

Coconuts

Yep, just your average coconuts. But look how nice they look! I just love that it‚Äôs so easy to find yummy fruit everywhere in Taiwan üôÇ

Sugar-Apples (aka Custard-Pineapple)

If you only clicked on this post because of that first pic, you‚Äôve scrolled down far enough to learn about them! These are sugar-apples. Again, they don‚Äôt taste at all like apples despite its name. I definitely have never see these in the states, but again, super common in Taiwan. They are custard-like inside, but unlike the Durian, no one thinks it smells bad, and most people think it tastes yummy!

Pin this!

Looking for more posts about my travel in Taiwan? There‚Äôs plenty here!

Sharing is caring!
